   1309.01  ORGANIZATION OF DIVISION OF BUILDING INSPECTION A ND REGULATION.
   The Division of Building Inspection and Regulation shall be known and
designated as follows:
(a)   Office.
(b)   Building structures including heating and air conditioning; but not
including electrical, plumbing and sanitation.
(c)   Electrical.
(d)   Plumbing and sanitation.  (Ord. 17-73.  Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.02  PERSONNEL OF DIVISION OF BUILDING INSPECTION.
   (a)   The personnel under “Office” shall be the Clerk-Treasurer and his
assistants;
 
   (b)   The personnel under the “Building Structures” shall be the Building
Inspector and shall be designated as the Building Inspector;
 
   (c)   The personnel under “Electrical” shall be the Electrical Inspector and
shall be designated as the Electrical Inspector;
 
   (d)    The personnel under "Plumbing" and "Sanitation" shall be as follows:
(1)    The Summit County Health Director is responsible for plumbing.
(2)    The Summit County Sanitary Engineer is responsible for connections to
the County controlled sanitary sewers.
(3)    The Village Director of Public Service is responsible for connections to
the Village controlled sanitary sewers.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.03  DUTIES OF CLERK-TREASURER.
   The duties of the Clerk-Treasurer and his assistants under "Office" shall be
to issue permits, accept fees for issuance of the permits thereof and to keep
the records of all permits issued and moneys collected. (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-
8-73.)
 
   1309.04  DUTIES OF BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The duties of the Building Inspector under "Building Structures"
shall be to determine compliance with this Code and check and approve plans for
the stability of the structures, means of egress, safety to life and property
from fire hazards incident to the design, construction, erection, alteration,
enlargement, repair, removal, moving, demolition, conversion, equipment use and
occupancy of the buildings or structures. The Building Inspector shall notify
the architect, engineer, contractor or owner of the approval or disapproval of
the plans in writing with copies of the approval or disapproval directed to the
Village Planning Commission and the Clerk-Treasurer.
 
   (b)    After approval of plans has been secured and a permit for
construction has been issued, the Building Inspector shall make the following
inspections:
(1)    After the excavation has been made and prior to the construction of the
footings.
(2)    After completion of the foundation walls and prior to framing of the
structure.
(3)    After completion of framing and prior to lathing and plastering.
(4)    After completion of structure and prior to occupancy.
         (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.05  AUTHORITY OF BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   The Building Inspector shall have authority to order the enforcement of all
laws, ordinances and regulations relating to the construction, alteration and
repair, removal, moving, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy, location and
maintenance of buildings and structures except as may be otherwise provided
for. He shall, when requested by the Mayor or Council or when the interests of
the Village so require, make investigations in connection with matters, under
his jurisdiction, referred to in this Code and render written reports on the
same. For the purpose of enforcing compliance with the provisions of this Code
and other pertinent laws and ordinances assigned to him for enforcement, he
shall issue such notices or orders as may be necessary. The Building Inspector
shall have the right to enter upon any premises, building or structure at any
reasonable time, in the performance of his duties to make an inspection except
that he shall not enter upon any premises, building or structure in instances
and under conditions that are in violation of the Constitution or laws of the
State of Ohio or of the Constitution or laws of the United States of America.
   No person shall obstruct or abuse the Building Inspector in the performance
of his duty.
   The Building Inspector shall identify himself when requested by presenting
any reasonable and customary evidence that he bears on his person. 
(Ord. 17-73.  Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.06  DUTIES OF ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR.
   The duties of the Electrical Inspector shall be to enforce the regulations
of this Code in accordance with the currently published rules and regulations
of the National Electrical Code and the National Safety Code as approved by the
American National Standards Institute, Inc.
(Ord. 17-73.  Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.07  DUTIES OF PLUMBING AND SANITATION PERSONNEL.
   The duties of the personnel under Plumbing and Sanitation shall be to
enforce the regulations of this Code in accordance with the current rules and
regulations of the Summit County Health Department and the Village.
(Ord. 17-73.  Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.08  BUILDING PERMIT APPLICATION. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section 1309.08 was repealed by Ordinance 88-1995.
 
   1309.09  PLANS AND ELEVATIONS TO BE SUBMITTED.
   (a)   Detailed plans and elevations drawn to scale of the proposed building
or structure, and any and all other plans and submission requirements required
by the Building and/or Zoning Code, shall be submitted to the Clerk of Council
and thereafter processed in accordance with  Chapter
1107 of the Zoning Code.
(Ord. 88-1995.  Passed 8-7-95.)
   (b)   The plans shall contain a location drawing showing the location of the
building or structure on the lot in relation to the building set-back lines and
side lines clearances.  If the proposed construction is in an allotment of
record then the plans must show the name of the subdivision or allotment with
volume and page number, lot number and house number.  If additional adjacent
land has been purchased and is to be included in the property on which the
construction is proposed, then, the plans must show the name of the owner of
the property from whom the additional land was purchased.
 
   (c)   The owner’s name, address and telephone number and the contractor’s
name, address and telephone number must be submitted as part of the request for
a permit and this information must be attached to the plans that are submitted
in duplicate.
 
   (d)   Building plans are to be deposited with the Clerk-Treasurer who shall
then transmit them to the Planning Commission.  The procedure in routing of the
plans shall be as referred to in subsection (a) hereof.  A routing sheet shall
be maintained in the Village Hall on which shall be recorded the clearance date
on all plans.
 
   1309.10  PERMIT EXPIRATION; FEE NOT TO BE REFUNDED.  (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section 1309.10 was repealed by Ordinance 88-1995.
 
   1309.11  POSTING OF PERMIT CARD.
   No operations or work of any kind, requiring a permit shall be commenced
until the permit card therefor is procured and posted in a conspicuous place
near the front of the premises and in such a position as to permit the
inspectors of the Village and Summit County Department of Health to make the
required entries thereon regarding inspection of the work.  The card shall be
preserved and remain posted until the completion of the work for which it was
issued.  No person shall remove or cover the permit card until the work for
which the card was issued has been approved by the Building Inspector. 
(Ord. 17-73.  Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.12  CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY REQUIRED. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section 1309.12 was repealed by Ordinance 88-1995.

   1309.15  CONFLICT OF LAW.  (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section 1309.15 was repealed by Ordinance 88-1995.
 
   1309.16  USE OF CURBS AND CURB CUTS REGULATED.
   The use and care of streets and sidewalks in conjunction with building
construction shall be as follows:
(a)   Where concrete curbs are in place in any street in the Village, a permit
is required to make any entrance cut, downspout openings and connections.  All
curb cutting, downspout openings and connections shall be made by the Village
with the Street Commissioner determining the necessary width of cut and number
of downspout connections.
   A three day notice shall be given to the Street Commissioner before the work
is to be done and no construction or excavating shall be commenced until all
cuts are made.
   All vehicles must use the driveway entrance from the street for ingress and
egress to any property.
(b)    When no concrete curb exists in a street, a steel culvert shall be
ordered from and installed by the Village before any excavation or construction
is commenced and the Street Commissioner shall determine the necessary size and
length of the culvert.
   (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1309.17  METAL CULVERT REQUIRED PRIOR TO BUILDING.
   It is called to the attention of the contractor that he shall avoid any
obstruction in the flow of storm water in the gutters or drainage ditches.
Prior to unloading building materials, a corrugated metal culvert pipe of
sufficient diameter to transport storm water under the driveway entrance shall
be installed in accordance with Ordinance 2-1957, included in this code and
made a part thereof, except that, no corrugated metal culvert shall be less
than ten inches in diameter, inside dimension. Homes or structures with single
garages shall have corrugated culvert pipe of not less than sixteen feet in
length. Homes or structures with double garages shall have corrugated culvert
pipe of not less than twenty-four feet in length. If, in the opinion of the
Planning Commission, no useful purpose shall be gained by the installation of
the corrugated metal culvert pipe at the time their permit is issued, then this
requirement may be waived by the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)

   1313.01  BUILDING PERMIT AND BOND REQUIRED.
   (a)   The owner of property, his general contractor or subcontractor or any
person acting on his behalf, shall before commencement of any work, secure the
necessary permits from the Division of Building Inspection and Regulation, and
deposit a bond therewith as set forth in this chapter.
 
   (b)   Signs, fences and accessory buildings less than 100 square feet are
exempted from the building permit requirements but must meet all other
requirements as set forth in Chapter 11 of the Planning and Zoning Code of the
Village of Silver Lake and Section
1313.10 - Zoning Fees as set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 77-1997.  Passed 10-20-97.)
 
   1313.02  BUILDING FEES.
   Pursuant to a contract between the Village of Silver Lake and the City of
Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, building inspection services for the Village shall be
performed by the City of Cuyahoga Falls, with the exception of commercial
plumbing.  Accordingly, the Village adopts the applicable building and grading
fees as established by contract to be applied as and when required by Village
permit regulation and consistent therewith, and as such fees are changed and
amended from time to time, which fees are incorporated herein by reference. 
Such fees shall be paid to City of Cuyahoga Falls by the applicant.  Commercial
plumbing permit fees for structures are established and administered by the
County of Summit.
(Ord. 30-2008.  Passed 3-17-08.)
 
   1313.03  STREET AND SIDEWALK FEES AND BOND.
   (a)   New Residence Class A and Additions Thereto.  Before a new residence
Class A or additions thereto containing a cubage of 10,000 feet or more are
constructed, a permit fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be paid, which sum
shall cover the expense of a minimum of two inspections of the streets and
public ways in the vicinity of the proposed new construction by the Director of
Public Service.  One of the inspections shall be made prior to any construction
and one shall be made at the completion of all construction.  In addition, each
individual making an application for a permit shall deposit cash or a certified
check in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00).
 
   (b)   New Buildings or Structures Class B, Class C and Class D and Additions
Thereto.  Before a new building or structure Class B, Class C and Class D or
additions thereto containing a cubage of 10,000 feet or more are constructed a
permit fee of eighty dollars ($80.00) shall be paid which sum shall cover the
expenses of a minimum of four inspections of the streets and public ways in the
vicinity of the proposed new construction by the Director of Public Service. 
One of the inspections shall be made prior to any construction and one shall be
made at the completion of all construction.  In addition, each individual
making an application for a permit shall deposit cash or a certified check in
the amount of eight hundred dollars ($800.00).  (Ord. 38-1979.  Passed 8-6-79.)
 
   1313.04  REFUND OF BOND DEPOSIT.
   Ninety days after the completion of the construction or the granting of a
certificate of occupancy all or any portion of the bond deposit not needed for
the return of the streets and public ways to their original condition, or
repair and replacement of damage to trees or other Village property, shall be
returned to the individual posting the bond upon approval of the Director of
Public Service.  It is specifically provided that the bond deposit shall not be
the limit of the property owner, agent or contractor’s liability if the actual
damages exceed the amount of the bond.  (Ord. 38-1979.  Passed 8-6-79.)

CHAPTER 1317
Enforcement and Penalty
 
1317.01    Enforcement responsibilities.
1317.02   Notice to remedy Code violation.
1317.03   Power to stop work due to violation.
1317.04   Existing rights and actions not affected.
1317.05   Fee doubled for commencing work without permit.
1317.06   Home owners exemptions.
1317.99   Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Duties and authority of Building Inspector - see BLDG.
1309.04,
1309.05
      Duties of Electrical Inspector - see BLDG.
1309.06
      Duties of plumbing and sanitation personnel - see BLDG.
1309.07
 
 
   1317.01  ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The regulations under this Building Code shall be enforced by the Village
acting through the Planning Commission, Building Inspector, Clerk-Treasurer,
Electrical Inspector, the Director of Public Service, the Summit County
Sanitary Engineer and the Summit County Health Department. Owners, builders,
contractors, architects and engineers are not to be relieved of their
respective responsibilities as a result of not having read the Code in its
entirety and becoming familiar with the enforcement through the jurisdiction of
the Village, the Summit County Sanitary Engineer and the Summit County Board of
Health.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1317.02  NOTICE TO REMEDY CODE VIOLATION.
   Whenever the Building Inspector is satisfied that a building or structure,
or any work in connection therewith, the erection, construction or alteration,
execution or repair of which is regulated, permitted or forbidden by this Code,
is being erected, constructed, altered or repaired in violation of a detailed
statement or plan submitted and approved thereunder, or of a permit or
certificate issued thereunder, he may serve a written notice or order upon the
person responsible therefor directing discontinuance of such illegal action and
the remedying of the condition that is in violation of the provisions or
requirements of this Code.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1317.03  POWER TO STOP WORK DUE TO VIOLATION.
   Whenever, in the opinion of the Building Inspector, by reason of defective,
reckless, careless or other illegal work in violation of a provision or
requirement of this Code, the continuance of a building operation is contrary
to public welfare and safety, or when the required permit has not been obtained
or has not been posted as required, he may order, either orally or in writing,
all further work to be stopped and may require suspension of work until the
condition in violation has been remedied.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1317.04  EXISTING RIGHTS AND ACTIONS NOT AFFECTED.
   All other ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this Code
shall be and the same are hereby repealed, but the repeal of such ordinances or
parts of ordinances shall not affect any right, property or claim which was or
is vested in the Village, or any act done, or right accruing or accrued, or
established, or any suit, action or proceeding had or commenced before the time
when this Code shall take effect; nor shall such repeals, amendments or changes
affect any offense committed, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any
suit or prosecution pending at the time when this Code shall take effect, under
any of the ordinances or sections thereof so repealed. (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-
73.)
 
   1317.05  FEE DOUBLED FOR COMMENCING WORK WITHOUT PERMIT.
   No person, partnership, firm or corporation, whether owner or agent thereof,
shall begin work in the Village for erection, construction, alteration, repair,
enlargement, remodeling, demolition, moving or any other type of building or
structural operation until a building permit therefor has been obtained and
posted, and the applicable fee paid to the Clerk-Treasurer. In the event of a
violation hereof by commencing work without first obtaining a proper building
permit and having paid the appropriate fee in advance an increase in the amount
of 200 percent of the applicable permit fee shall be assessed by the Clerk-
Treasurer.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1317.06  HOME OWNERS EXEMPTIONS.
   No provision or provisions of this Code shall be interpreted to require that
the bona fide owner and occupant of a single family dwelling shall be licensed
who personally or with casual assistance performs work upon the premises
occupied or to be occupied by the owner thereof as the owner's established
residence.
   The owner shall be issued a permit for the work providing he satisfactorily
qualifies through an oral test given by the appropriate inspector of the
Village relating to the work, and files with the Clerk-Treasurer an affidavit
stating and alleging the above facts.
   All such work shall be done in conformity with the provisions of this Code,
and the laws of the State of Ohio and no work shall be done unless all permits
required are obtained.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1317.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Building Code shall be fined not more
than fifty dollars ($50.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
CHAPTER 1321
Classification of Buildings
1321.01   Building classifications designated.
1321.02   Analysis of classification.
 
 
   1321.01  BUILDING CLASSIFICATIONS DESIGNATED.
   Every new and existing building, or structure, shall, for the purpose of
this Building Code, be classified according to its use or occupancy as a
building or structure of one of the following classes:
Class A Residential.
Class B Schools, libraries, churches, Village Hall and places of assembly.
Class C Special, including electric substations, buildings required to house
facilities of public and privately owned utilities, such as, power and light,
communications, gas, sanitary pumping stations, water pumping and water
storage.
Class D Nonconforming. Nonconforming uses shall be greenhouses and apartment
buildings that were established prior to the passage and approval of this Code.
   Whenever there is any uncertainty as to the classification of a building,
the Building Inspector shall determine the classification within which it
falls.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1321.02  ANALYSIS OF CLASSIFICATION.
   (a)    Class A Residential. Class A includes every building or part of a
building, which is occupied, arranged, intended or designed to be occupied by
one family or household.
 
   (b)    Class B Churches, Schools, Libraries, Village Hall and Places of
Assembly.
(1)    Residential parts of churches when used in this Code without other
qualification, means a structure of not more than three stories in height
occupied exclusively for residential purposes by not more than two families.
(2)    Schools under this classification shall include all public, parochial
and private schools, colleges, academies and seminaries, and does not include
nursery day schools.
(3)    Libraries are buildings or structures of one or more rooms used for the
purpose of acquiring knowledge and may be used for the purpose of assemblage.
(4)    Village Hall is the building or structure where the business affairs of
the Village are conducted and where the general public of the Village may
assemble.
(5)    Places of assembly are any buildings or structures used exclusively for
the purpose of assembly by the general public of the Village.
 
   (c)    Class C Special.  Class C includes electric substations, buildings
required to house facilities of public and privately owned utilities, such as,
power and light, communications, gas, sanitary pumping stations, water pumping
and water storage.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1325
Construction Standards and Materials
 
1325.01   General provisions.
1325.02   Interior wall coverings for dwellings and insulating materials.
1325.03   Tests for materials of doubtful quality.
1325.04   New materials, appliances and methods.
1325.05   Materials and Methods Board; duties and membership.
1325.06   Testing of materials and methods.
1325.07   Grading and filling.
1325.08   Excavations.
1325.09   Foundation waterproofing, and floodproofing.
1325.10   Retaining walls in flood plain area.
1325.11   Engineer approval in flood plain area.
1325.12   Minimum first floor grade.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Conformance to National Electrical Code - see BLDG.
1335.01
      Plumbing installation - see BLDG.
1339.05
 
 
   1325.01  GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)    One and Two Family Dwelling Codes and Ohio Basic Building Code. All
work performed under this chapter of the Building Code for one and two family
dwellings shall conform to the requirements of the One and Two Family Dwelling
Code or the Ohio Basic Building Code whichever is the more strict, excepted as
herein amended or herein otherwise provided.
 
   (b)    Location of Structure. The structure shall be located on the lot to
conform to the limits as designated under the Planning and Zoning Regulations.
The overhang of the roof shall be considered the point from which the minimum
dimension is measured in determining the distance from the building or
structure to the lot line or side line.
 
   (c)    Garages. A garage attached to a house or separated from a residential
building by an open or enclosed breezeway and where the door of the garage
opens on a street, facing a street, shall have the interior of the garage
finished in such a manner that exposed studding, ceiling joists or roof rafters
shall not be visible from the street when the doors are open. All regulations
in regard to fire resistant construction shall be observed.
(Ord. 15-1980. Passed 5-5-80.)
 
   1325.02  INTERIOR WALL COVERINGS FOR DWELLINGS AND INSULATING MATERIALS.
   Interior wall coverings for dwellings, and insulating materials and their
accessories for all buildings shall be of a type which will not create an undue
hazard to life or property and, in that respect, shall be subject to the
approval of the Building Inspector. The provisions of this section shall not
supersede or annul provisions of this Code covering approvals by the Board of
Zoning and Building Appeals or provisions of the Code which establish the
required qualities, referred to in this section, for such materials. (Ord. 17-
73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.03  TESTS FOR MATERIALS OF DOUBTFUL QUALITY.
   In case there is reason to doubt the quality of a material to be used in a
building or structure, the Building Inspector may require tests to be made to
establish its suitability or to determine whether it conforms to the intent and
purpose of this Code.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.04  NEW MATERIALS, APPLIANCES AND METHODS.
   When a person, firm or corporation desires to use a material, appliance or
method of construction which is newly developed or which is not otherwise
provided for in this Code and which is a factor in the compliance with the
intent and purpose of this Code, and for the use of which material, appliance
or method of construction the Board of Zoning and Building Appeals has not duly
adopted a rule or regulation, such person, firm or corporation shall apply to
the Board of Zoning and Building Appeals for a rule or regulation permitting
the use of the new material, appliance or method of construction. The Board of
Zoning and Building Appeals may use the Materials and Methods Board established
by the Tri-County Building Officials Association to determine suitability of
any material or method.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.05  MATERIALS AND METHODS BOARD: DUTIES AND MEMBERSHIP.
   The Materials and Methods Board shall be referred to herein as the MMB. The
TriCounty Building Officials Association shall be referred to herein as the
TBOA. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the MMB to determine the
suitability of any material or method, or to determine whether it will conform
to the intent and purpose of this Code.
   The MMB shall be comprised of five members, one member shall be a registered
professional engineer, one shall be a registered architect, one shall represent
the building materials industry, one shall represent the residential builders,
and one shall represent the general public. The term of office shall be five
years, one to be selected each year.
   The members of the MMB shall be selected by the majority of all the members
of the TBOA.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.06  TESTING OF MATERIALS AND METHODS.
   The Building Inspector shall have the authority to demand a test of any
particular item of construction selected by him from a job, or at the source of
supply.
   Authorized agencies and/or laboratories, for approval of materials and
methods shall be as follows, and as amended from time to time: Akron
University, Kent State University, Ohio State University, Michigan State
University, University of Illinois, University of Indiana, Pittsburgh Testing
Laboratories, Case Western Reserve University, Research Institute Laboratory of
NAHB, and such agencies as are approved by the TBOA.
   Results of tests by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, if the test is
conducted under the supervision of the MMB, or one of its authorized agents,
shall be approved and accepted.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.07  GRADING AND FILLING.
   (a)    The owner or possessor of any lot or land may grade or improve the
surface of the lot or land to correspond with the established grade of the
street upon which the lot or land abuts without incurring liability, provided
he gives the adjoining owner or owners thirty days notice in writing of the
proposed grading or improvement. When any lot or land is so graded or improved
the owner of any adjoining lot or land shall, at his or their own expense build
such retaining walls or foundations as may be required to safely protect his or
their land and the structures erected thereon.
 
   (b)    The owner or possessor of any lot or land who fills a lot so that the
surface of its shall be above the established grade of the street upon which
the lot or land abuts and above the existing surface of any adjoining lot or
land shall, at shall at his own expense, build such retaining walls as may be
required to properly protect all adjoining property from damage on account of
the fill.
 
   (c)    The owner or possessor of any lot or land, who grades the lot or
land, except as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) hereof, so that the
level of the lot or land is below the established grade of the street or
streets, on which the lot or land abuts, shall at his own expense, build such
retaining walls as may be required to protect the adjoining property from
damage because of such grading below the established grade or grades, and he
shall give the owner or owners of the adjoining lots or land which may be
affected thirty days written notice before beginning the grading.
 
   (d)    Mortar in new walls must be thoroughly set or the walls shall be
adequately braced or loaded before backfilling is commenced. Grading and
backfilling shall be done in a manner which will not cause injury to foundation
walls.
 
   (e)    The owner or possessor of any lot or land may grade or improve the
surface of the lot or land, or excavate thereon, only if he provides a system
for drainage of surface and subsurface waters which shall handle such water
flowing into and from such lands in a manner which preserves the essential
characteristics of adjoining lands, and those lands which receive water run-off
from the lot to the grade by providing for the prevention of downstream
flooding, erosion and pollution.
 
   (f)    No person shall proceed with the grading, excavating or filling of
any property within the Village of Silver Lake unless, and until such person
has secured a grading permit from the Village by submitting a grading and
excavating plan to the Village Engineer. Approval of such plan shall be
performed by the same process required for the approval of a building permit as
set forth in this Code, and the enforcement of this regulation shall be done in
the same manner as is done for a building permit. The grading plan shall
include, at a minimum the following, and such other requirements as are deemed
necessary by the Village Engineer to achieve the purposes of this regulation
and other requirements of the Code:
(1)    The location of the proposed work in relation to the improved and
unimproved areas adjacent thereto.
(2)    The location and extent of the grading, excavating or filling, with an
approximate estimate of the quantities of the item involved and the nature of
the final surfacing.
(3)    Profiles or cross sections showing the elevation of the original or
existing ground surface, together with the elevations of the proposed finished
ground lines and the slope lines of all fills and cuts.
(4)    Provision for bonding fills to existing ground surfaces and method of
consolidation and compaction of fills.
(5)    Provision for the drainage of existing and new ground surfaces and
surface drainage for the protection of cuts and fills and nearby lands and
waters.
(6)    Provision for the drainage of subsurface water where subsurface water is
known or believed to exist.
(7)    Where retaining walls or other structures are to be used to assist in
the support of cuts and fills, a design of such walls or structures shall be
included in the plans.
(8)    Where underground drainage structures are to be used, drawings showing
locations, sizes and profiles shall be submitted with drainage and runoff
studies for analysis by the City Engineer. Such drawings shall indicate
connections with existing City drainage structures, and calculations shall
indicate that existing drainage structures shall not be overloaded.
(9)    Where underground drainage structures are not to be used, but runoff is
to be collected in existing or proposed surface structures or drainage ditches,
calculations shall be submitted and shall indicate that existing or proposed
drainage structures and drainage ditches shall not be overloaded.
 
   (g)    The above provisions are intended to supplement, not replace, any
similar requirements in the Village Subdivision Code or Zoning Code.
(Ord. 24-1993. Passed 4-19-93.)
 
   1325.08  EXCAVATIONS.
   (a)    Whoever makes any excavation shall, at his or their own expense,
properly guard and protect the same so as to prevent the excavation from being
or becoming dangerous to life, limb or property.
 
   (b)    Whoever makes any excavation below the established grade shall
prevent the adjoining soil from falling in. When any excavation is carried to a
depth of nine feet or less below the established grade, the owner or owners of
any adjoining or contiguous wall or walls, structure or structures, which may
be affected by the excavation, shall reinforce it if required and so support it
by proper foundations that it or they shall be and remain as safe as before the
excavation was commenced.
 
   (c)    When an excavation for any purpose shall be carried to a depth of
more than nine feet below the established grade, the foundations of all
adjoining buildings shall be extended to the full depth of nine feet by the
owner thereof, as provided heretofore. The person or persons causing the
excavation to be made shall, at his or their own expense, so preserve any
adjoining or contiguous wall or walls, structure or structures from injury due
to that part of the excavation which is more than nine feet below the
established grade and support it by proper foundations so that the wall or
walls, structure or structures, shall be and remain as safe as before the
excavation was commenced.
 
   (d)    An excavation may be made, with proper precautions, to the full depth
of any existing foundation on an adjoining lot without liability attaching to
the person or persons making the excavation. In all cases where excavating is
proposed, the owner or owners of all buildings or structures, which may be
affected by such excavating, shall be notified in writing, by the person who
proposed to excavate, at least thirty days before commencing work. When a
permanent excavation is made on any lot, the person or persons causing the
excavation to be made shall build a retaining wall to give lateral support to
the earth, and the retaining wall shall be carried to the height of the
established grade, and be properly protected by a coping and a substantial
railing three feet, six inches high with not less than one intermediate rail.
The person or persons making the excavation shall build the retaining wall at
his or their own expense, except when the excavation extends to a building and
is protected thereby and as specifically provided for along lot lines. (Ord.
17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1325.09  FOUNDATION WATERPROOFING AND FLOODPROOFING.
   (a)    In all areas within the flood plain as defined by the Federal
government; or
 
   (b)    Any time any portion of a structure, including footers and
foundations is below an elevation of 998 feet above sea level, the additional
requirements of subsections one through five shall be imposed.
(1)    All retaining walls and other walls below grade shall be designed to
resist lateral soil pressure with due allowance for hydrostatic pressure and
for all superimposed vertical loads.
(2)    All foundation slabs and other footings subjected to water pressure
shall be designed to resist a uniformly distributed uplift equal to the full
hydrostatic pressure.
(3)    Foundation walls shall be designed to resist frost action and to support
safely all vertical lateral loads. The maximum stresses due to combined load
shall be within the values specified for the materials used in the
construction. Unless properly reinforced, tensile stresses shall not exceed
those permitted in plain masonry.
(4)    Exterior walls below grade and the cellar floors enclosing habitable or
occupiable rooms or spaces below grade shall be reinforced to withstand water
pressure as determined by a registered civil or structural engineer or
registered architect.
(5)    Exterior walls below grade enclosing habitable or occupiable rooms or
spaces shall be protected with not less than one coat application of approved
waterproofing paint or one-half inch parging coat of portland cement mortar or
other dampproofing covering.
         (Ord. 16-1980. Passed 5-5-80.)
 
   1325.10  RETAINING WALLS IN FLOOD PLAIN AREAS.
   In all areas described in subsections (a) and (b) of Section
 1325.09, retaining walls shall be designed and constructed as follows:
(a)    General. Walls built to retain or support the lateral pressure of earth
or water or other superimposed loads shall be designed and constructed of
approved masonry, reinforced concrete, steel sheet piling or other approved
materials within the allowable stresses of accepted engineering practice.
(b)    Design. Retaining walls shall be designed to resist the pressure of the
retained material, including both dead and live load surcharges to which they
may be subjected, and to insure stability against overturning, sliding,
excessive foundation pressure and water uplift.
(c)    Hydrostatic Pressure. Unless drainage is provided, the hydrostatic head
of water pressure shall be assumed equal to the height of the wall.
(d)   Coping. All masonry retaining walls other than reinforced concrete walls
shall be protected with an approved coping.
(e)    Foundation Walls. Foundation walls of buildings and structures which
serve as retaining walls shall conform to the above requirements or shall be
strengthened with buttresses or additional wall thickness to resist lateral
soil and hydrostatic pressure when subjected thereto. (Ord. 17-1980. Passed 5-
5-80.)
 
   1325.11  ENGINEER APPROVAL IN FLOOD PLAIN AREA.
   In all areas described in subsections (a) and (b) of Section
1325.09, all plans for construction shall be approved by a registered civil or
structural engineer or registered architect prior to the submission of such
plans to the Village for a building permit.
(Ord. 18-1980. Passed 5-5-80.)
 
   1325.12  MINIMUM FIRST FLOOR GRADE.
   All buildings constructed within the Village shall have a first floor grade
of not less than 1,001 feet above sea level.
(Ord. 23-1981. Passed 6-15-81.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1329
Heating and Air Conditioning

1329.12   Building permit required; permit revocation.
1329.13   Inspection of new work.
1329.14   Power of Building Inspector to stop work.

      Heating and air conditioning fees - see BLDG.
1313.06
 
 
   1329.01  GENERAL STANDARDS.
   All work performed under this chapter of the Building Code shall conform to
the requirements of the National Warm Air and Air Conditioning Code and the
specifications of the Mechanical Contractors Association of America except as
herein amended.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.02  PURPOSE AND APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   It is the intention of this chapter to regulate the construction,
installation, alteration and inspection of heating, ventilating and air
conditioning in the Village. The Code shall apply to the installation,
alteration, repair and/or replacement of all piping apparatus, appliances,
devices and/or accessories for warn air heating, wet heat, ventilating and air
conditioning systems, gas and oil burners, stokers, and/or unit heaters,
conversion burners used or to be used in or about any building, structure or
premises of any kind within the Village.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.03  TRI-COUNTY HEATING CONTRACTORS' LICENSES HONORED.
   A heating contractor shall be permitted to install heating, ventilating and
air conditioning units in the Village if he has been fully licensed to perform
this specific work in Summit, Medina or Portage Counties.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.04  DEFINITION.
   A heating contractor means any person who proceeds with or has charge of the
laying out or installation, alteration, replacement or repair of any heating,
ventilating or air conditioning system, or the installation of an oil burner,
stoker, unit heater or conversion burner, in any building or structure within
the limits of the Village.
   Nothing in this Code shall be construed to prevent a firm or corporation
from engaging in the heating or air conditioning business, provided the firm or
corporation steadily employs in a supervisory capacity the holder of a heating
contractor's license as provided herein.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.05  LICENSE REQUIREMENT.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in or work at the business of
contracting in the Village, without first receiving a license as provided for
in this Code.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.06  UNLAWFUL SIGN DISPLAY.
   No person, firm or corporation, other than a licensed heating contractor,
shall expose a sign "Heating Contractor" or use any other advertising
pertaining thereto.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.07  LENDING OF LICENSE PROHIBITED.
   No heating contractor shall lend his license or take a permit for heating in
his name for the use of any person or allow the use of his name directly or
indirectly for the purpose of obtaining a permit.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.08  UNLAWFUL HIRING.
   No person, owner, agent or occupant of any building or premises shall aid or
abet any heating contractor in the violation of this Code or connive at its
violation or employ or hire an unlicensed heating contractor or person or
permit his employment.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.09  UNLAWFUL CONTRACTING.
   No person, firm or corporation other than a licensed heating contractor,
shall enter into an agreement or contract, written or verbal, with any owner,
agent or occupant to make any connection to a heating or air conditioning
system, or to repair, replace, alter, construct or add to any heating or air
conditioning system in or about any building, structure or premises of any kind
or class used or to be used for any purpose whatsoever within the limits of the
Village.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.10  RESPONSIBILITY OF HEATING CONTRACTOR.
   A heating contractor shall be responsible for the heating and air
conditioning done by him or under his direction and for the compliance with all
the provisions of this Code applicable to heating and air conditioning.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.11  ISSUANCE OF PERMITS.
   Heating permits will be issued only to licensed heating contractors or to a
bona fide owner of a single one-family dwelling, when the dwelling is occupied
by or is designed and intended to be occupied by the owner as his own single
family dwelling and the owner shall file with the Clerk-Treasurer an affidavit,
stating and alleging all of the above facts.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.12  BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED; PERMIT REVOCATION.
   No permit shall be issued for the installation of a heating, ventilating or
air conditioning system in any building until the required building permit has
been issued by the Clerk-Treasurer. Any permit issued for heating, ventilating
or air conditioning in violation of any of the laws of the Village as a result
of false information or misrepresentation shall be revoked. (Ord. 17-73. Passed
5-8-73.)
 
   1329.13  INSPECTION OF NEW WORK.
   In any new building or addition, immediately upon the completion of those
portions of the installation which are thereafter to be concealed or covered up
in any heating or air conditioning installation, the heating contractor shall
notify the Building Inspector, giving the location of the work that such
portions of the installation are ready for inspection; and no person, firm or
corporation shall lath over, plaster or cover up any heating work before the
work has been inspected and the building permit card stamped approved. The
Building Inspector shall have the right to have removed all the lath, plaster
or other covering which may have been placed over such work before it has been
inspected. Final inspection of the plant shall be made after the whole is
connected up and ready to operate.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.14  POWER OF BUILDING INSPECTOR TO STOP WORK.
   Whenever it comes to the attention of the Building Inspector that any
heating, ventilating or air conditioning installation is being done contrary to
or in violation of the Heating Code, the Building Inspector shall have the
power to order any such work immediately stopped and may revoke any permits for
the work. Any such order to stop work or any revocation of a permit shall be in
writing. No person, firm or corporation shall continue to proceed with any
heating installation after receipt of any such notice until the heating
installation has been made to comply with all the provisions of the Heating
Code.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.15  MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be minimum requirements,
adopted for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the community.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.16  SIZE OF WARM AIR FURNACE.
   When a warm air furnace is replaced or a new one installed, the unit must be
of sufficient size to heat the building, irrespective of the size of the warm
air pipe or return air ducts, unless the unit is made part of the present
permanent system as an auxiliary
system. (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.17  PERMANENT HEATING SYSTEM DEFINED.
   For the purpose of enforcing this Code, any heating system which is a
physical part of the building and is attached thereto and considered a part of
the real estate is declared permanent.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1329.18  INSTALLATION STANDARDS.
   Warm air heating appliances and air conditioning shall be installed in
accordance with the National Warm Air and Air Conditioning Code.
   Wet heat appliances shall be installed in accordance with the
recommendations and specifications of the Mechanical Contractors Association of
America or the Ohio Building Code where applicable.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1335
Electrical
 
 
1335.01   General provisions.
1335.02   Definitions.
1335.03   Enforcement.
1335.04   Temporary use of adjacent facilities restricted.
1335.05   Service equipment.
1335.06   Installation requirements.
1335.07   Required lighting.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
         Duties of Electrical Inspector - see BLDG.
1309.06
         Electrical fees - see BLDG.
1313.07
         Homeowner's exemptions - see BLDG.
 1317.06
 
 
   1335.01  GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   All work performed under this Building Code shall conform to the
requirements of the National Electrical Code, 1978 edition, which is hereby
adopted by reference except as herein amended.
   Licensing of contractors and work by owners shall conform to the
requirements of Chapter
1329 of this Code. The purpose of this chapter of the Code is the practical
safeguarding of persons and of buildings and their contents from hazards
arising from the use of electricity for light, heat, power, radio, signaling
and for other purposes.
   This chapter contains basic minimum provisions considered necessary for
safety. Compliance therewith and proper maintenance will result in an
installation essentially free from hazard, but not necessarily efficient,
convenient or adequate for good service.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.02  DEFINITIONS.
   In general, terms used only in a single section are defined in the section
concerned. For electrical terms not defined in the Code, refer to the American
National Standards Institute, Inc.'s Definitions of Electrical Terms, ANSI C-
42. (Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.03  ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter is intended to be suitable for mandatory application by
governmental bodies exercising legal jurisdiction over electrical installations
and for use by insurance inspectors. The administrative authority supervising
such enforcement of the chapter will have the responsibility for making
interpretations of the rules, for deciding upon the approval of equipment and
materials, and for granting the special permission contemplated in a number of
the rules.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.04  TEMPORARY USE OF ADJACENT FACILITIES RESTRICTED.
   In addition to the requirements and regulations outlined herein the
electrical contractor or owner is encouraged not to use the existing electrical
facilities of the adjacent properties. but make arrangements to have separate
temporary service supplied to his project during construction. If service is to
be secured from buildings or structures on adjacent properties then prior
permission in writing must be secured from that owner.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.05  SERVICE EQUIPMENT.
   (a)    Service equipment installed, irrespective of type, should be of such
capacity as to permit the full utilization of the capacity of the service
entrance conductors installed at the time of the original installation.
 
   (b)    Service entrance equipment shall be a minimum of 100 ampere capacity
per family in single or multiple dwellings and either of the automatic breaker
or the safety type fuse.
 
   (c)    The size of service entrance conductors for single family dwellings
shall be three wire, 100 ampere, copper conductors or conductors of equivalent
capacity, from service drop to service entrance equipment.
 
   (d)    All service ground wire shall be a minimum gauge of No. 4 copper, to
be installed subject to the approval of the Electrical Inspector, and shall be
grounded in accordance with the provisions of the National Electrical Code.
Ground rod, when used, must be installed approximately one inch from building
wall and driven to the finished grade level and shall be left accessible for
inspection.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.06  INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS.
   Electrical wiring and devices shall be installed in accordance with the
National Electrical Code.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
   1335.07  REQUIRED LIGHTING.
   In any room where there are no light fixtures to be installed a switch plug
must be provided.
   All outside door entrances must have a light on the outside of the entrance
with a switch located inside the door entrance.
   All stairs in the building shall be lighted by a light conveniently located
to serve the purpose involved.
(Ord. 17-73. Passed 5-8-73.)
 
 
 
 
CHAPTER 1339
Sanitation and Plumbing

1339.02   Sanitation responsibilities.

         Sewers - see S. U. & P.S. Ch.
927
